description: A Federation colony officially catalogued as Epsilon Boötis III.[90] The legendary starship captain named Garth was an Izarian. The planet's capital is New Seattle.
name: Izar

description: a Class D planet featured in the TOS episode "The Devil in the Dark", where a pergium mining colony resides. The USS Enterprise is called there to investigate the unexplained deaths of miners only to reveal the world is inhabited by the Horta, a silicon-based organism defending its territory.
name: Janus VI

description: Second planet in the Beta Caeli star system.[91]
name: Japori II

description: Site of a Federation prison, referred to as a "stockade" by Ensign Ro who had spent time there after being court martialed for disobeying orders during a mission on Garon II.[27]
name: Jaros II

description: A moon of Bajor, featured in the DS9 episode "Progress".
name: Jerido

description: Site of the Federation colony New Providence which was destroyed by the Borg in 2366.[92]
name: Jouret IV

description: Federation colony handed over to the Cardassians in 2370.[93]
name: Juhraya

description: or Sol V. The largest gas giant in the Sol System. The EMH was developed at Jupiter Station which orbits the planet.[94]
name: Jupiter

description: Riker mentions that he had gone on a diplomatic mission to Kabatris, where he was required to wear furs.[95]
name: Kabatris

description: Planet in Federation space sought by the Dominion for its native tri-nucleic fungi which could replenish supplies of ketracel-white.[64]
name: Kabrel I

description: Homeworld of the Kaelon species. The planet was orbiting a dying star, home world of Dr. Timicin and his people.[96]
name: Kaelon II

description: The Enterprise-D carries a delegation of Ullians to Kaldra IV.[65]
name: Kaldra IV

description: Planet in Pakled territory, rich in magnasite deposits.[97]
name: Kalla III

description: Planet whose emperor of the 7th dynasty was named Darmok.[5]
name: Kanda IV

description: Homeworld of the Kantare species.[98]
name: Kantare

description: System in the Gamma Quadrant with thick asteroid belts.[99]
name: Kar-telos

description: Dominion allied homeworld of the Karemma species, located in the Gamma Quadrant. In DS9 episode "Starship Down", Quark learns of the existence of the Karemma. In DS9 episode "The Search" Sisko hopes the Karemma will lead him to the Founders.
name: Karemma

description: World destroyed in the 14th century when its star went supernova. Under the influence of a Kataan probe, in just 25 minutes, Capt. Picard lives a lifetime of events on this world.[100]
name: Kataan

description: Homeworld of the V'naree species.[101]
name: Katarrea VII

description: Home planet of the Kavarian tiger-bat, which Jake Sisko was researching.[102]
name: Kavaria

description: Planet where the Enterprise-D dropped off a colony of nanites that were infecting the computer core. The nanites developed a collective intelligence and consciousness and went to war with the crew after scientist Paul Stubbs killed some of them. Peace was eventually made and Captain Picard declared them a new species and gave them a home on the planet.[103]
name: Kavis Alpha IV

description: One of the Maquis crewmen, a Bolian, was wearing a medallion he made in a Kazlati design while he visited their homeworld.[104]
name: Kazlati homeworld

description: Delta Quadrant planet notable for its unusual toroidal shape caused by a natural tachyon energy field. In 2376, the USS Voyager was caught in the planet's gravity which disrupted the tachyon field and caused seismic activity on the surface that threatened the lives of native inhabitants.[105]
name: Kelemane's Planet

description: Homeworld of the primitive Kelis species located in the Delta Quadrant.[106]
name: Kelis' homeworld

description: Planet that suffered a drought and sought help with the Federation for weather control technology.[107]
name: Kelton IV

description: Planet in the Andromeda Galaxy, and homeworld of the Kelvanite species who explored the Milky Way Galaxy in hopes of colonization.[108]
name: Kelva

description: (a.k.a. Kelvas Prime), Dominion controlled planet featured in the DS9 episodes "Tacking Into the Wind", and "The Dogs of War".
name: Kelvas V

description: Homeworld of Dr. Dalen Quaice, who the Enterprise-D picked up from Starbase 133.[109]
name: Kenda II

description: Mythological planet sought by the Skrreea woman Haneek and her people after their homeworld was conquered by the Dominion. In 2370, Haneek came to DS9 believing Bajor was Kentanna and sought resettlement there, but the Bajoran provisional government refused to grant them asylum and the Skrreea resettled on Draylon II.[110]
name: Kentanna

description: Neelix and Tuvok visited this Delta Quadrant planet, homeworld of both the Kesatians and the shadowy Ba'Neths, on a negotiation mission.[111]
name: Kesat homeworld

description: Planet with two nation-states, the Kes and the Prytt, whose common border is divided by a force field, as they are highly suspicious of each other. While the Kes have applied for Federation membership, the Prytt remain a highly insular and closed society. The mutual race hate between the Kes and the Prytt led the crew of the USS Enterprise-D to recommend that Kesprytt III be denied Federation membership at that time.[112]
name: Kesprytt III

description: Federation colony and birthplace of B'Elanna Torres. She and her mother were the only Klingons on the planet.[113]
name: Kessik IV

description: Homeworld of the Enolians.[114] NOTE: The planet's name may come from the organic chemistry term Keto-enol tautomerism.
name: Keto-Enol

description: Planet on the Klingon side of their border with the Romulan Star Empire. Location of Camp Khitomer, site of the First Khitomer Accords, a series of treaties resulting from peace talks between the two empires and the United Federation of Planets in 2293.[115] Also the location of the Khitomer Outpost, site of the Khitomer Massacre in c. 2346, when 4,000 Klingon colonists were killed by Romulans as the result of Ja'rod's defection to the Romulans.[116] Other Klingons were captured by the Romulans and imprisoned on penal colony Carraya IV.[117]
name: Khitomer (QI'tomer in Klingon)

description: Home of the Ferengi entrepreneur Plegg, who was credited for holosuite technology.[118]
name: Khosla II

description: Kiberian fire diamonds are mentioned in DS9 episode "Rules of Acquisition."
name: Kiberia

description: Home of the Klaestronian species. It is located in the Alpha Quadrant near Bajor. The UFP visited the planet in 2339 to mediate the Klaestronian Civil War.[119][120]
name: Klaestron IV

description: Planet nearly identical to Daled V.[121]
name: Klavdia III

description: Spock was asked a question about a technological device from Kelndeth during his memory test on Vulcan.[122]
name: Klendeth

description: Once home of two sentient species, the non-corporeal and corporeal Koinonians. The corporeal species ended up destroyed themselves and only the non-corporeal entities remain.[123]
name: Koinonian homeworld

description: Cardassian controlled planet featured in the DS9 episode "Afterimage."
name: Kolandra

description: A planet near the Romulan Neutral Zone that was featured in the movie Star Trek Nemesis. The planet is inhabited by a hostile post-industrial era species. The crew of the Enterprise-E find the remains of an android clone of Data named B-4.
name: Kolarus III

description: Planet in Cardassian space.[124]
name: Kora II

description: Site of an abandoned mining colony. Odo chases the changeling fugitive Laas there.[125]
name: Koralis III

description: System where families aboard Deep Space Nine were relocated in 2370 when a revolution on Bajor seemed likely.[126]
name: Korat

description: Planet with a Cardassian outpost where in 2372, the Cardassians and Bajorans have a conference to share intelligence about the Klingons. The Klingons later attack the outpost.[127]
name: Korma

description: Quark gave Dr. Bashir a bottle of champagne from Korris I.[129]
name: Korris I

description: Home planet of Campo, whom Lwaxana Troi planned to marry.[130]
name: Kostolain

description: Kantare colony, a light year from the Kantare homeworld.[98]
name: Kotara Barath

description: Delta Quadrant planet.[60]
name: Kotati

description: Garek told the Klingon Duras sisters they could obtain fine silk from Kraus IV.[131]
name: Kraus IV

description: Pronunciation of Qo'noS, homeworld of the Klingons. See Qo'noS.
name: Kronos

description: Homeworld of the Kreetassan species. Capt. Archer's dog Porthos caught a deadly pathogen here.[132]
name: Kreetassa

description: The Kressari are a race of traders in herbaceous goods who are accused of weapons smuggling. The name of their planet is not mentioned.[133]
name: Kressari homeworld

description: (a.k.a. Krios Prime) A Klingon controlled homeworld of the Kriosian species.[134][135][136] NOTE: It is uncertain if Krios and Krios Prime are the same planets since the planet changes color (from blue to green) between the two TNG episodes and the Klingons are not mentioned in either TNG's "The Perfect Mate" or Enterprise's "Precious Cargo".
name: Krios

description: Planet controlled by the Ktarian species. After visiting the planet, Chakotay accidentally removed a sacred stone from a Ktarian burial site as a memento and was accused of desecration.[101]
name: Ktaria VII

description: Homeworld of the Ktarian species.[137] Etana Jol, a Ktarian, tried to take over the Enterprise-D for her people by introducing a mind-controlling game to the crew.[138]
name: Ktaris

description: Supposed homeworld of the Dominion allied Vorta species in the Gamma Quadrant, but its existence couldn't be verified since Eris, a Vorta operative, and the source of the information, was unreliable.[87]
name: Kurill Prime

description: The home world of the Kurlan civilization, which died out thousands of years ago.[78]
name: Kurl

description: Delta Quadrant planet occupied by the Krenim, "erased from existence" by a timeline disruption.[26]
name: Kyana Prime

description: Unexplored planet being surveyed by the USS Defiant in 2371 but, the mission was cut short when the crew detected gravimetric distortions in the Trialus system.[139]
name: Kylata II

description: Delta Quadrant planet where the USS Voyager became caught up in a conflict. 700 years later, a backup copy of Voyager's holographic doctor is reactivated to prove the innocence of the crew, who are still labeled as war criminals.[140]
name: Kyria

description: System of uninhabited planets featured in the TOS episode "The Doomsday Machine" that is discovered by the USS Constellation to have been destroyed by a planet-eating machine.
name: L374

description: Planet near the Gamma Quadrant opening of the Bajoran Wormhole. Artifacts and ruins were found on L-S VI that were similar to those seen on the Founder's Homeworld.[118][141]
name: L-S VI

description: Ferengi inhabited planet where the flower Zan periculi grows.[143]
name: Lappa IV

description: In the 2009 Star Trek movie, as the Romulans are attacking Vulcan, Capt. Pike orders Spock that if all else fails, he should rendezvous with the rest of the fleet in the Laurentian System.
name: Laurentian System

description: Cardassian planet with a labor camp where Thomas Riker was imprisoned.[145]
name: Lazon II

description: Jadzia Dax owned a plant from Ledonia III.[146]
name: Ledonia III

description: Homeworld of the Ledosian and Ventu species.[147]
name: Ledos

description: Homeworld of the Legaran species, who exist in thick pools of liquid maintained at 150° Celsius.[148]
name: Legara IV

description: Federation colony.[149]
name: Lemma II

description: Planet with a ceremonial drink called Tanagra.[5]
name: Lerishi IV

description: a Federation colony.[80]
name: Levinius V

description: Picard offered to take Ardra to the Ruins of Ligillium, site of the lost Zaterl Emerald, if she won her arbitration.[150]
name: Ligillium

description: Planet where Dr. Bashir went to see a gallery of paintings by Prof. Gideon Seyetik.[49]
name: Ligobis X

description: A tropical planet, home of the Ligonians who visited by the USS Enterprise-D to secure procurement of a viral antidote need on Styris IV.[151]
name: Ligon II

description: Location of a Federation science station.[152]
name: Ligos VII

description: Capt. Picard mentioned that the Enterprise had visited this planet, which has an odd orbit.[153]"
name: Lima-Sierra III

description: Homeworld to the Lissepian species.[154] Cmdr. Sisko suggests the Lissepians could be involved in weapons smuggling.[155]"
name: Lissepia

description: Delphic Expanse home of the Loque'eque species who lost the ability to reproduce and fell on the verge of extinction. They tried to preserve their kind by engineered a genetic retrovirus that changed infected members of other humanoid races into their own.[156]
name: Loque'eque homeworld

description: Planet in the Gagarin Radiation Belt with pink/purple cloud layers, known to have 5000 subspecies of termites.[157]
name: Loracus Prime

description: Planet with a fragment of Dr. Galen's genetic code puzzle to find the origin of humanoid species.[78]
name: Loren III

description: Planet, whose actual name is not mentioned, whose natives, called Lorillians, breathe methyl oxide, presumably a component of its atmosphere.[158] However, it is known that the Lorillian homeworld is a planet of Gamma Leporis, which is only 29 light-years from Earth.
name: Lorillian homeworld

description: Location of a Cardassian outpost and subspace relay station.[127]
name: Loval

description: Homeworld of the Lurian race. Morn is a Lurian.[159]
name: Luria

description: Location of a Federation Starbase, Enterprise-D's destination at the end of the episode.[160]  The Enterprise received a coded message from Federation Command on Lya III, about suspected Romulan activity in the Neutral Zone.[161]
name: Lya III

description: Planet where the Enterprise-D traced the smuggler Kivas Fajo's ship in orbit after figuring out Data had been kidnapped by him.[85]
name: Lya IV

description: System with a Federation colony located near the Federation-Cardassian border.[162]
name: Lyshan

description: Homeworld of the Lysian Alliance who were at a decades long war with the Satarrans species. In 2368, the USS Enterprise-D crew had their memories erased and sent false orders by a Satarran spy who posed as second in command to attack the Lysian Alliance headquarters.[17]
name: Lysia

description: a Class M planet featured in TOS episode "The Man Trap". The planet is also called Crater's World, and also known as Fotialla by the extinct natives that once lived there.
name: M-113

description: Tzenkethi settlement attacked by Ambassador Krajensky (a disguised changeling) who commandeered the USS Defiant in an attempt to start a war with the Federation.[1]
name: M'kemas III

description: Mentioned in TNG episode "Heart of Glory". It is an outpost possibly under Klingon control. It was claimed as the destination of Korris and his fugitive Klingons. Note: It may simply be spelled as M-Z-V as "Zed" is the typical British/Canadian pronouncement of the letter "Z" instead of "zee".
name: M-Zed V

description: Gas giant planet with a Class M moon. In the 19th century, criminals from the Ux-Mal system were exiled to the moon where their consciousness was separated from their physical bodies by the planet's electromagnetic fields. Some time in the 2160s, the prisoners attempted to escape by inhabiting the bodies of crew members of the Federation starship USS Essex but the plan failed when the ship crashed on to the surface. The beings later take possession of Data, Troi, and O'Brien to hijack the Enterprise-D.[3]
name: Mab-Bu VI

description: So-called world where living machines built a gigantic vessel for the V'ger (Voyager 6) probe which came to Earth to search for its creator. Spock saw the machine-planet as a full-scale holographic image in V'ger's immense memory chamber along with other representations of objects that V'ger encountered along its journey.[4]
name: Machine planet

description: The fourth planet of the FGC-892 system, which is discovered with a human society modeled after the ancient Roman Empire of Earth.[5]
name: Magna Roma

description: Guinan once broke up a fight in Ten Forward with a weapon she described as "a little souvenir I picked up on Magus III."[6]
name: Magus III

description: Destination of the USS Enterprise NCC-1701 in TOS episode "The Galileo Seven". The primary city of New Paris, where they were supposed to drop off medical supplies before the Galileo shuttlecraft is lost.
name: Makus III

description: Planet with a Federation medical facility.[7]
name: Malaya IV

description: Third planet in the Mu Ceti system. Homeworld of the Malcorians who were on the verge of warp capability. Commander Riker goes to the planet disguised as one of the inhabitants but his cover is blown and causes a panic among officials when they discover an alien living among them.[8]
name: Malcor III

description: Planet with a colony called Darmok.[9]
name: Malindi VII

description: Homeworld of the Leyrons known for having developed a written language before a spoken one.[10]
name: Malkus IX

description: Homeworld of the Malon species in the Delta Quadrant. Supposedly beautiful, but kept that way only because the Malon dump their industrial waste into outer space.[11]
name: Malon Prime

description: planet devastated by the crystalline entity.[12]
name: Malona IV

description: An inhabited planet mentioned which was destroyed by the Nomad probe.[13] This planet may be in the Malurian system, home system of a species illicitly mining veridium on the Akaali homeworld.[14]
name: Malur

description: Planet where Worf saw proximity detectors in use, which helped him to recognize them on Turkana IV in the TNG episode "Legacy".
name: Manu III

description: Federation colony located near Sector 441.[15]
name: Manzar colony

description: Location of a Klingon outpost[16]
name: Maranga IV

description: An unexplored world.[17]
name: Marcos XII

description: A planet mentioned in the TOS episode "Requiem for Methuselah". The planet was home to a famous painter known as Sten.
name: Marcus II

description: Homeworld of the Oolan species.[18]
name: Marejaretus VI

description: Delta Quadrant planet, home of the peaceful and telepathic Mari, visited by Voyager.[19]
name: Mari homeworld

description: Planet along a Valerian smuggling route.[20]
name: Mariah IV

description: Gas giant planet where the USS Raman was lost.[21]
name: Marijne VII

description: Home of the SS Mariposa science colony, which is made up of clones of the five original colonists who survived when the ship crashed there. The planet has large rings and a thick reddish atmosphere. Mariposa in Spanish means butterfly.[22]
name: Mariposa

description: Homeworld of the Marlonian species. Capt. Picard, along with Guinan, Keiko O'Brien, and Ensign Ro spend shore leave here.[23]
name: Marlonia

description: a colonized sister planet of Earth. Its capital is Utopia Planitia and also has an extensive shipbuilding facility in orbit around the planet.
name: Mars (Sol IV)

description: Planet in the Cardassian DMZ, where Maquis coloists evicted from Salva II resided for a while.[24]
name: Marva IV

description: Planet where Dr. Phlox once practiced.[25]
name: Matalas

description: Planet where Dr. Noonien Soong and Juliana O'Donnel were married.[27]
name: Mavala IV

description: A star system where Captain Picard and his previous command, the USS Stargazer, came under attack by an unknown ship, later identified as a Ferengi vessel.[28]
name: Maxia Zeta

description: Homeworld of the Mazarite species. V'Lar is the Vulcan ambassador to Mazar.[29]
name: Mazar

description: Planet where Dr. Bashir attended a medical conference but later was abducted by the Dominion and replaced with a Changeling spy.[30]
name: Meezan IV

description: Prison planet mentioned by Odo.[31]
name: Meldrar I

description: A "friendly planet" that Cmdr. Riker recommends Moriarty and Regina Bartholomew to visit when they leave the Enterprise-D.[32]
name: Meles II

description: Planet known for its plasma geysers.[26]
name: Melnos IV

description: A planetoid which contains a massive Federation database. The Zetarians killed everyone on the planet.[34]
name: Memory Alpha

description: Federation library facility.[35]
name: Memory Delta

description: Federation library facility.[35]
name: Memory Gamma

description: Gamma quadrant planet where O'Brien and Bashir complete a bio-survey just before they are captured by Jem'Hadar on Bopak III.[37]
name: Merik III

description: Sol I; in the fictional Adventures of Captain Proton holo-series, Mercury has a mining colony.[38]
name: Mercury

description: The strange Gamma Quadrant homeworld of the Meridian species in the Trialus system, whose star creates a buildup of quantum energy that periodically shifts Meridian between two dimensions every sixty years. The Meridians spend part of it in a physical existence and the other as incorporeal energy. They mark the passing event with the "First Meal" and "Last Meal" celebrations.[39]
name: Meridian

description: Federation colony.[40]
name: Midos V

description: Q reminds Picard that he once saved an ambassador's life on Milika III.[41]
name: Milika III

description: a doomed planet with a Federation research base. The Minara star goes supernova and destroys the planet.[42] Kirk (in Dr. Janice Lester's body) mentions Minara as the home of the Vians; it is unclear whether he is referring to Minara II.[43]
name: Minara II

description: Planet whose natives are at war with the Vek.[44]
name: Minnobia

description: a planet visited by the USS Enterprise-D in the TNG episode "The Arsenal of Freedom." The culture of the world gained notoriety for the development of advanced weapon systems which they traded to other cultures who were at war. It was discovered by the Enterprise crew that Minos was a "Frankenstein planet," in that the culture was destroyed by their own military products.
name: Minos

description: Federation colony with 2 million settlers whose territory was disputed by the Cardassians.[45]
name: Minos Korva

description: a planet mentioned in the Enterprise episode "Strange New World" as being representative of planets capable of sustaining humanoid life, otherwise known as an M-Class or a Class M planet.
name: Minshara

description: A planet visited by the USS Enterprise-D in the TNG episode "Who Watches the Watchers". Home of a primitive planet of Vulcanoids who mistake Picard for a god.
name: Mintaka III

description: The third planet of the FGC-347601 system. A remarkable world, found to be a nearly exact duplicate of Earth. It was named after Miri, a young survivor of a deadly plague that killed all the planet's adult population.[46]
name: Miri

description: Planet near the Romulan Neutral Zone.[47]
name: Miridian VI

description: Delta Quadrant planet, home of the Mislenite species.[48]
name: Mislen

description: Delta Quadrant planet in Bothan territory.[49]
name: Mithren

description: Second planet in the Zeta Ursa Majoris star system. Homeworld of the pacifist Mizarian species, noted by Jean-Luc Picard as having been conquered six times throughout history.[50]
name: Mizar II

description: A planet with an isolationist colony, threatened by a stellar core fragment.[51]
name: Moab IV

description: System with at least one inhabited planet with a non-humanoid civilization. When young Geordi La Forge was living with his father, he was assigned to the system to study invertebrates.[52]
name: Modean

description: Planet in Cardassian space with a Dominion shipyard.[53][54]
name: Monac IV

description: A planet composed entirely of water.[55]
name: Monea

description: A planet with a human civilization that had recently ended a brutal civil war when the Enterprise-D visited it.[56]
name: Mordan IV

description: At the end of the TNG episode "Tapestry," Picard tells Riker about his run-in with a couple of surly Nausicaans on Morikin VII during his sophomore year at the Academy.
name: Morikin VII

description: Klingon planet with a subspace monitoring station.[57]
name: Morska

description: Destination of the Enterprise after it destroys the asteroid that threatened Tessen III.[58]
name: Moselina system

description: Planet inhabited by a colony of androids who abducted the crew of the Enterprise NCC-1701. It was named after the con-artist Harcourt Fenton Mudd whom James Kirk encountered there.[59] Mudd was also indicated on a map of the galaxy behind Dexter Remmick in TNG episode "Conspiracy."
name: Mudd

description: Planet the Enterprise-D had left on stardate 45156.1 before encountering a quantum filament.[60]
name: Mudor V

description: Planet that Q offered to take Vash to see their famous star dancers.[61]
name: Mundahla

description: Planet where Vash was wanted (dead-or-alive) for stealing the "Crown of the First Mother."[61]
name: Myrmidon

description: Planet of the Taqua Tribe.[62]
name: Nagor

description: Planet where an epidemic of Correllium Fever broke out.[63]
name: Nahmi IV

description: Voyager episode "Vis à Vis".
name: Nanibia Prime

description: Delta Quadrant planet visited by the USS Voyager.[64]
name: Napinne

description: Klingon colony settled in the 22nd century.[35][65][66]
name: Narendra III

description: The homeworld of the ill-tempered Nausicaan species; Enterprise episode "Fortunate Son". Garak mentions that the person who tried to kill him may have been a Nausicaan whose wedding suit he misplaced.[68] The system's primary and Nausicaa's position in the system are not specified, nor has any explanation been given for the generally hostile Nausicaan temperament in canon sources.
name: Nausicaa

description: Delta Quadrant planet visited by Voyager.[69]
name: Nechani homeworld

description: A Federation colony. In 2369, Jadzia Dax opened subspace links to the Nehru and New France colonies when she tried to purge the Deep Space Nine systems of "Pup", a sentient computer program that threatened the station.[70]
name: Nehru colony

description: System which was mentioned as a place where Kivas Fajo could have fled to after kidnapping Lt. Cmdr. Data.[71]
name: Nel Bato

description: A planet within the Romulan Neutral Zone featured in the TNG episode "The Defector". A Romulan defector seeks asylum aboard the Enterprise with information that the Romulan Empire is building an invasion force on this world. Arriving there, the Enterprise crew find no evidence of military activity and the Defector realizes it was just a test of his loyalty. Riker recalls the Nelvana III incident when he meets Tomalak aboard Enterprise-E.[47]
name: Nelvana III

description: Site of the transporter accident that created Thomas Riker, a duplicate of William Riker.[72]
name: Nervala IV

description: Featured in the Voyager episode "Pathways".
name: Nessik

description: Planet once visited by Travis Mayweather. The natives of the planet were easily offended and would have duels over trivial matters.[73]
name: Neubilia Prime

description: also known as Zeta Boötis III, is a planet featured in the TOS episode "A Private Little War" where Klingons, whose laws include no analog for the UFP's Prime Directive, are caught influencing the technological development of the planet's primitive inhabitants.
name: Neural

description: First Gamma Quadrant colony by Bajorans, established in 2370. A few months later, the colony's inhabitants were massacred by the Jem'Hadar, but not without a fight. This incident added to many of the other sparks that ignited the Dominion War.[74][75]
name: New Bajor

description: Federation colony named after Brooklyn, New York.[76]
name: New Brooklyn IX

description: Unpopulated Delta Quadrant planet, named by Capt. Janeway and Cmdr. Chakotay who were forced to live there for a time after contracting an incurable virus.[77]
name: New Earth

description: A Federation colony. In 2369, Jadzia Dax opened subspace links to the Nehru and New France colonies when she tried to purge the Deep Space Nine systems of "Pup", a sentient computer program that threatened the station.[70]
name: New France colony

description: birthplace of Miranda Vigo, who Capt. Picard believes bore his son.[78]
name: New Gaul

description: Homeworld of the Halanan species.[79]
name: New Halana

description: Also known as Soporo, is a Trill controlled planet.[80]
name: New Sydney

description: The resettlement planet of the surviving Vulcan people after the destruction of their home world in the 2009 Star Trek movie. In Star Trek Into Darkness, Spock contacts his older, alternate universe self, (played by Leonard Nimoy), and now living on New Vulcan. The planet is not shown in the film.
name: New Vulcan

description: Planet famous for its moons. Khan vowed to chase Admiral Kirk "Round the "Moons of Nibia..."[81]
name: Nibia

description: A class M planet featured in the opening scenes of the Star Trek Into Darkness movie. The world was home to a primitive race of humanoids who were being threatened by an erupting volcano. Captain Kirk conducted a mission to stop the eruption, during which events led to the USS Enterprise being seen by the aliens and violating the Prime Directive. Despite Kirk having saved Spock's life during the mission, Spock places him on report, and Admiral Pike strips Kirk of his command of the Enterprise.[82] The world appears[to whom?] to take its name from the Babylonian term "Nibiru".
name: Nibiru

description: Destination of the Enterprise-D after its mission to Bre'el IV.[83]
name: Nigala IV

description: a desert planet whose system lies at a point between the Romulan, Klingon, and Federation space. It was featured in the movie Star Trek V: The Final Frontier. It was known as the "Planet of Galactic Peace" and was established as a neutral ground for negotiations between the three governments, but it quickly became an interstellar cesspool of crime and poverty. In 2287, Spock's half-brother Sybok recruited many of these desert dwellers into his "Galactic Army of Light" and took one representative each of the Federation, the Klingon Empire, and the Romulan Star Empire hostage to lure, to the planet, a starship they could ultimately hijack and take to the mythological planet Sha Ka Ree.
name: Nimbus III

description: Planet known for its dancing girls, seen in a holodeck simulation.[84]
name: Ninipia Prime

description: Alpha Quadrant planet.[85]
name: Nivoch

description: Delta Quadrant planet, homeworld of the Norcadian species, known for its beautiful beaches and art museums.[86][87]
name: Norcadia Prime

description: Planet in the Delphic Expanse where a deuterium station is located.[88]
name: Norellus

description: Site of a Federation colony and outpost.[89]
name: Norkan

description: Federation colony.[90] Scotty was on his way to Norpin V aboard the USS Jenolan when he crashed onto the Dyson sphere.[91]
name: Norpin V

description: The rumored origin of Guinan.[92]
name: Nova Kron

description: Homeworld of the Nyrian species.[93]
name: Nyria III

description: Homeworld of the Shamans.[4]
name: O'Ryan's Planet

description: Planet where an outbreak of plasma plague infected the northern continent.[92]
name: Oby VI

description: Desert homeworld of the Ocampa species, the fifth planet from its star in the Delta Quadrant. Its atmosphere lacks nucleogenic particles and is incapable of producing rain. The Ocampa have lived underground for 500 generations. The Kazon-Ogla have a colony on the surface.[94]
name: Ocampa homeworld

description: Planet where the Enterprise-D was sent to for a diplomatic mission.[95]
name: Oceanus IV

description: Klingon planet with a warrior academy.[16]
name: Ogat

description: Federation colony with extensive recreational facilities.[96]
name: Ogus II

description: An outpost on Ohniaka III was attacked by Lore's Borg in the beginning of TNG episode "Descent."
name: Ohniaka III

description: a planet featured in the episode "The Omega Glory" (TOS). It is discovered that the planet developed along similar historical lines as Earth where two "superpower" nations arose, the Khoms and the Yangs, and fought a cold war that ended in the near destruction of all inhabitants.
name: Omega IV

description: Cardassian planet with a shipyard.[98]
name: Omekla III

description: Planet whose ancient population was wiped out by nuclear war. Gary Seven's computer compared Earth's Cold War of the late-20th century to that of the situation of Omicron IV.[99]
name: Omicron IV

description: Third planet orbiting Omicron Ceti, better known as Mira. A Federation planet with a simple-lived farming colony featured in the episode "This Side of Paradise" (TOS) where the populace has been taken over by strange mind-affecting spores. The planet appears yellow-green-orange from space. Its primary emits deadly Berthold radiation, of which the spores prove to be the only known combatant, actually thriving on the radiation itself. The fifth planet in the same star system is called Omicron Ceti V, Mira V, or Dytallix B.
name: Omicron Ceti III

description: Planet used by the crew of the Enterprise NCC-1701 in 2267.[100] Strange machinery below the planet made realistic creations of whatever a visitor imagined. A temporary "glitch" in the system caused some of the creations to become deadly until the problem was corrected by the planet's caretaker.
name: Omicron Delta

description: A system, one planet of which had a small scientific colony where Dr. Noonien Soong built and activated the android Data and his brother Lore.[102] All life on the planet was killed by a crystalline entity lured from space to the planet by Lore.[12] Later, Data learns why he was given the memories of the colonists of Omicron Theta.[27]
name: Omicron Theta

description: A Federation colony world mentioned in the episode "Mudd's Women" (TOS) as the destination of Harcourt Fenton Mudd where he planned to sell his beautiful women companions.
name: Ophiuchus III

description: Planet in the Delphic Expanse.[88]
name: Oran'taku

description: Site of the famous "Battle of Orelious" where the Menthars and Promellians fought to their mutual extinction. In 2366 the Enterprise-D falls for a power draining trap that was still set in an asteroid field near the planet.[103]
name: Orelious IX

description: Delta Quadrant planet.[104]
name: Orendal V

description: a non-aligned planet featured in the episode "Errand of Mercy" (TOS) where the Federation and Klingons battle for control. The seeming primitive inhabitants reveal themselves to be powerful incorporeal beings, and pacifists. They force the Klingons and humans to end their hostilities, and establish the Neutral Zone as part of the Treaty of Organia.
name: Organia

description: Formerly uninhabited planet in Cardassian space, where the Obsidian Order and the Romulan Tal Shiar mounted forces to attack the Dominion in 2371.[68][98]
name: Orias III

description: Quark plans to smuggle a load of kemacite to Orion.[105] Homeworld of the Orion species; the planet orbits the star Pi³ Orionis.
name: Orion

description: Location of the Institute of Cosmology.[106]
name: Orion I

description: As Chakotay starts his fight, Tom Paris tells him that the odds at Vegas, Mars and Orion III are against him, and that his fight is being called "The Disaster in the Delta."[107]
name: Orion III

description: Also known as Delos III, this is home to the Ornarans who have become addicted to the drug felicium by the inhabitants of Delos IV, the Brekkians.[108]
name: Ornara

description: Destination for the Enterprise-D in TNG episode "The Offspring".
name: Otar II

description: Andorian planet featured in the Enterprise episode "Cease Fire" and "Kir'Shara".
name: Paan Mokar

description: An ocean planet that often is used for crewmember shore leave and diplomatic conferences.  The planet is administered by Federation Governor Delaplane. It was first mentioned the TNG episode "Conspiracy", in which the Enterprise-D was en route there for shore leave. In the second season,[18] the Enterprise takes Lwaxana Troi and a pair of Antedeans (who travel in a self-induced catatonic state) to Pacifica for a diplomatic conference.
name: Pacifica

description: Home of the Palamarian species.[44]
name: Palamar

description: Cardassian colony in the Cardassian DMZ.[24]
name: Panora

description: The Paraagans established a mining colony on another world with an atmosphere that reacts explosively with plasma. In 2152, an Enterprise NX-01 shuttle craft causes the atmosphere to ignite which killed 3,600 colonists. The cause of the blast was traced back to Suliban sabotage.[109]
name: Paraagan homeworld

description: Gamma Quadrant planet and home of the Paradan species.[76]
name: Parada II

description: The largest planet in the Parada system with seven moons. Miles O'Brien used the gravity of one of the moons to outmaneuver a pursuing runabout.[76]
name: Parada IV

description: A neutral conference planet where the Enterprise-D was taking dignitaries of the warring Selay and Antican species.[110]
name: Parliament

description: Planet where Quark discovered rich sources of the valuable mineral feldomite. His discovery caused the crash of the Sepian Commodities Exchange.[44]
name: Parsion III

description: the Enterprise had just completed a magnetic wave survey of this planetary system when it encountered a small probe.[111]
name: Parvenium system

description: The Doctor's holowife brews him a new blend of coffee from Paxsor III.[112]
name: Paxsor III

description: system that was the origin of a distress signal from Dr. Paul Manheim.[113]
name: Pegos Minor

description: Planet with two inhabited moons (Alpha and Beta). The people of Alpha moon developed a power source which tapped the magnetic energies of the main planet, but it also caused ecological damage to the Beta moon and started a war.[114]
name: Peliar Zel

description: Original destination of the USS Enterprise-D before it was hijacked by the Bynars.[101]
name: Pellius V

description: Homeworld of the Pendari species.[86]
name: Pendari

description: Pentarus system, Pentarus II, III, IV, and V.[115]
name: Pentarus

description: Cardassian colony.[116]
name: Pentath III

description: A planet facing traumatic climate change due to an asteroid strike.[117]
name: Penthara IV

description: Lifeless planet with a methane atmosphere. In 2152 Capt. Archer assists T'Pol in tracking down a Vulcan fugitive who escaped to the planet's moon.[118]
name: Pernaia Prime

description: a Federation colony visited by the Enterprise-D.[56]
name: Persephone V

description: World with a Vulcan monastery, which hides a secret listening post.[119] P'Jem orbits Luyten's Star.
name: P'Jem

description: Planet where the Shakespearean acting troupe led by Anton Karidian was performing, when the Enterprise was called there by Dr. Thomas Leighton, before the Enterprise transported the troupe to Benecia Colony.[120]
name: Planet Q

description: Holographic planet, featured in Voyager episode "Bride of Chaotica!".
name: Planet X

description: Homeworld of the Platonians.[121]
name: Platonius

description: An ice and rock dwarf planet. The Enterprise-B's maiden voyage was to take a group of media reporters out to Pluto and back again.[122]
name: Pluto

description: Class M world of the Delta Quadrant whose humanoid pre-warp civilization had city structures, provinces like Kalto, waterways and aqueducts, and a continental transport system in 2371. While in an alternate time loop the USS Voyager caused an accidental detonation of a polaric ion power grid and destroyed all life there, then helped restore the correct timeline using floating subspace fractures.[123]
name: Polaric Ion Planet

description: a Class M planet visited in an episode where the Enterprise crew encounters a powerful being who claimed to be the Greek god Apollo.[124]
name: Pollux IV

description: Delta quadrant planet that is the source of Porakan eggs. Neelix claims they are a galactic favorite when prepared with a little dill weed and a touch of rengazo.[125]
name: Porakas IV

description: Breen-controlled planet.[24]
name: Portas V

description: Guinan offers Data a drink that she heard about on Prakal II. Data quickly analyzes the drink as containing 87% Saurian Brandy, with the rest made up of Targ milk and Denevian Mead.[126]
name: Prakal II

description: Delta Quadrant planet with a civilization destroyed by robots. B'Elanna Torres activated one of the robots found floating in space by Voyager.[127]
name: Pralor homeworld

description: System where Dr. Timicin and the Enterprise conduct experiments to save the dying star of his home world Kaelon II.[128]
name: Praxillus

description: a moon of Qo'noS, and the Klingon Empire's prime source of dilithium. In 2293, Praxis exploded due to overmining and disregard for safety measures, blowing off about 60% of the moon's material and causing life-threatening damage to the atmosphere of Qo'noS. The military economy of the Klingon Empire also crumbled and as a result, forced them into a truce with the Federation.[57][125] How the damage was rectified has not been revealed, but Qo'noS is shown to remain habitable and still serves as the seat of power well into the 24th century.
name: Praxis

description: Planet that is source of the spice hajjlaran.[129]
name: Preenos

description: Talaxian mining colony.[130]
name: Prema II

description: Site of a battle in the mid-26th century between the Federation (led by the USS Enterprise, NCC-1701-J) and the Sphere Builders.[126][131] Note: Star Trek: Star Charts names the Procyon system as the home system of the Andorians; their homeworld of Andoria is a moon of the gas giant Andor, or Procyon VIII.
name: Procyon V

description: System where a popular nectar beverage comes from.[92]
name: Prometheus

description: Bajoran colony.[132]
name: Prophet's Landing

description: a planet with a Federation research station. In the TOS episode "The Naked Time", the Federation research station contained a virus which caused the Enterprise crew to go mad.
name: Psi 2000

description: Planet in Cardassian space raided by Bajoran resistance.[134]
name: Pullock V

description: An uninhabited planet featured in the TOS episode "Catspaw" and discovered to be the home of two powerful beings who toy with the crew of the Enterprise.
name: Pyris VII

description: Homeworld of the Pythron species.[135]
name: Pythro V

description: The main capital world of the Klingon Empire.  It is also referred to as Kronos (an alternative transliteration), Klinzhai, or Kling. The reference to a native or anything pertaining to the people, "Klingon," derives from this last reference.(see Omega Leonis)
name: Qo'noS

description: Homeworld of the Qomar species and the central world of the Qomar Planetary Alliance.[136]
name: Qomar homeworld

description: a colony world which was the destination of the Enterprise-D to help in the aftermath of a methane explosion.[137]
name: Quadra Sigma III

description: Location of Federation surplus depot "Z15", an orbiting station that manages a large fleet of mothballed starships and other unused equipment. The system is located 0.83 light-years from Galorndon Kor, which would probably place it close to the Romulan Neutral Zone.  The depot is known to hold at least a few offices and one lounge. The outpost is run by the Zakdorn species; the leader of the depot at the time was Klim Dokachin.[138]
name: Qualor II

description: Planet home to many sentient humanoid species, one of which is the industrious Quarren. Although advanced, the technology of the world used little automation and required lots of manpower and physical labor. The Quarren would capture crews of ships and bring them into the planet's complex workforce.[139]
name: Quarra

description: Cardassian colony attacked by the Maquis.[24]
name: Quatal Prime

description: Planet where several Enterprise-D children contracted a flu-like virus during a field trip[citation needed] which eventually infected nearly everyone on the ship.[140]
name: Quazulu VIII

description: Cardassian controlled planet destroyed by the Dominion.[141]
name: Quinor VII

description: Enterprise-D transports plasma plague samples to the Rachelis system.[1]
name: Rachelis

description: Planet Captain Picard says holds the last missing DNA fragment to throw off the Cardassians in their hunt for the genetic secret of the origin of humanoids species.[2]
name: Rahm-Izad

description: Planet in Cardassian space with a secret underground base located on its fourth moon.[3]
name: Rakal

description: Homeworld of the Vok'sha species.[4]
name: Rakella Prime

description: Planet where Odo transports a Rakhari prisoner.[5]
name: Rakhar

description: Delta Quadrant planet, home of the Rakosian species. The planet was mistaken by the Cardassian Dreadnought missile as the planet Aschelan V. The missile was destroyed by the USS Voyager before it could impact the planet where it would have killed over 2 million inhabitants.[6]
name: Rakosa V

description: Home of the deaf-mute negotiator Rivas.[7]
name: Ramatis III

description: Planet in the Delta Quadrant located near Krenim space. In an alternate timeline, the entire Ram-Izad species was erased from history by a Krenim temporal superweapon.[8]
name: Ram Izad homeworld

description: Homeworld of the Ramurian species.[9]
name: Ramura

description: Also called Delta Rana, Rana IV is planet with three moons whose Federation colony was wiped out by the Husnock species.[10]
name: Rana IV

description: Ens. Sonia Gomez, newly assigned to the Enterprise, mentions that she might have been assigned to duty on Ranous VI.[11]
name: Ranous VI

description: Planet mentioned for its frozen drink called Darmok.[12]
name: Ranza V

description: A once lifeless planetoid until Federation scientists used it as a testing ground for the Genesis experiments.[13]
name: Regula

description: Cardassian planet destroyed by Dominion forces.[14]
name: Regulak IV

description: Star system with three inhabited planets, Regulus III, IV and V. Regulus III has Starfleet Academy facilities.[15] Regulus V is the home of giant Eel Birds that return after 11 years to the cavern where they hatched to mate.[16]
name: Regulus

description: The Enterprise-D takes a mediator to this planet that is home world to both the Rekag and Seronian people.[18]
name: Rekag-Seronia

description: a Mars-like planet (possibly Class K) with a Federation base on the surface. Starfleet Academy also has a campus here which Wesley Crusher tried to gain acceptance into.[19]
name: Relva VII

description: Planet whose natives spin a crystalline webbing and use it as a building material. In 2371, Odo's criminal report speaks of a group of Nausicaan thieves break into a museum there.[20]
name: Remmil VI

description: The tide-locked companion of Romulus and home of the Reman species who have been enslaved by the Romulans.[21] It, alongside Romulus, was destroyed by the Hobus Supernova.[22]
name: Remus

description: Former Klingon controlled planet, annexed by neighboring alien culture who later abandons it.[23]
name: Rha'darus

description: Homeworld of the Rhaandarite species.[24]
name: Rhaandaran

description: Planet of which various locales were simulated by Quark's first holosuite programs.[25]
name: Rhymus Major

description: Geordi mentions that he has been living on Rigel III 25 years after leaving the Enterprise. [27]
name: Rigel III

description: Homeworld of Mr. Hengist, the Chief City Administrator at Argelius II, and also of the mass murderer of women known as Boratis.[28] Lwaxana Troi mentions that an astronomer from Rigel IV once named a star after her.[29] Mentioned as the site of a Trill-operated refinery.[30]
name: Rigel IV

description: Located in the Beta Orionis A system. The planet was visited by the USS Enterprise before the events in "The Cage". A conflict between the landing party, under Capt. Christopher Pike's command, and the Kaylar killed three crewmembers, including the captain's yeoman, and severely injured seven others.[32] The matte painting of the Rigel VII fortress seen in Pike's Talosian illusion was later re-used as Flint's home in "Requiem for Methuselah". Note: The true "Rigel" star is not in this system.
name: Rigel VII

description: The location of a dilithium mining colony where the conman Harcourt Fenton Mudd strikes a deal with the lonely miners to trade his women for dilithium.[34]
name: Rigel XII

description: formerly populated moon of Talax and home of Neelix. All life was destroyed by the Haakonian Metreon Cascade invented by Dr. Jetrel.[35]
name: Rinax

description: Also called Epsilon Ceti B II, located about 88.2 light-years from Earth, known for its beauty and relaxing tropical atmosphere. It is a world commonly sought by interstellar vacationers and starship crews on shore leave.[36][37][38] The planet orbits several stars and its climate is controlled by a weather modification network, with the natural climate being extremely violent. Risians are extremely open and will freely share their planet, and even themselves, with vacationers; a practice known as "Jamaharon".[39] Perhaps uncoincidentally, the name given to the fun-loving planet is also the Spanish word for "laughter", and phonetically remotely similar to the German word Reise, which translates as "travel" or "trip".
name: Risa

description: Delta Quadrant planet known for its "Zoth-Nut" soup.[40]
name: Rivos V

description: Planet visited by Cmdr. Benjamin Sisko and Curzon Dax who were cornered by hostile aliens on the surface.[41]
name: Rochanie III

description: The home planet of the Romulan people and the capital world of the Romulan Star Empire. Romulus shares its orbit with a binary companion Remus.[21] It, alongside Remus, was destroyed by the Hobus Supernova.[22]
name: Romulus

description: Planet in the Cardassian DMZ. Ensign Ro Laren was sent on a covert mission to infiltrate Maquis rebel cell hiding there.[42]
name: Ronara Prime

description: Planet within Cardassian space used by the Dominion as a cloning facility.[43][44]
name: Rondac III

description: Planet with an unusual asteroid ring that sparkles with colored energy bursts which likewise creates music-like tones in the planet's atmosphere. Wesley Crusher shows a holodeck simulation of the rings to Salia.[45]
name: Rousseau V

description: One of the planets visited by Dr. Galen in his search for DNA clues to the origin of humanoid races.[2]
name: Ruah IV

description: A utopian planet visited by the USS Enterprise-D whose inhabitants, the Edo, are watched over by powerful dimensional entities they worship as their god.[46]
name: Rubicun III

description: Planet with a Kazon colony. A member of a rival Kazon set planned to attack the colony by hijacking the USS Voyager.[47]
name: Runara IV

description: A frozen Klingon controlled planet which contained a penal colony, known for its harsh conditions and dilithium mines. Captain Jonathan Archer (along with his attorney Kolos) were sentenced by a Klingon tribunal to work in the planet's dilithium mines for the rest of Archer's life and for one year, respectively, until Archer was rescued by his crew.[23] Captain Kirk and Dr. McCoy were imprisoned there after their sentencing for the murder of Klingon Chancellor Gorkon.[48] The planet is named after a Siberian penal colony in War and Peace.[49] It is also the name of the penal colony that Captain Nemo and his crew escaped from and avenged in the 1954 double-Oscar-winning film 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea (1954 film).
name: Rura Penthe

description: Non-affiliated homeworld of the Rutian and Ansata species located in Federation space. In 2366 the Enterprise-D drops off medical supplies there.[50]
name: Rutia IV

description: Delta quadrant planet, fourth from its unnamed sun, visited by Voyager. It is inhabited by the secretive Sakari people who went underground to avoid detection by the Borg.[51]
name: Sakari homeworld

description: Planet under the control of the dictator Sural, known for beheading his rivals as well as his own parents.[6]
name: Sakura Prime

description: Former Federation colony world annexed into the Cardassian DMZ where colonists battled with Cardassian forces.[52]
name: Saltok IV

description: Federation colony annexed to the Cardassian DMZ.[53]
name: Salva II

description: Planet where Lt. Worf and his former love interest K'Ehleyr first met each other in 2359.[54]
name: Samrin's Planet

description: Recreational planet.[55]
name: Sarona VIII

description: Also known as Beta Niobe I, this class M planet was visited by the USS Enterprise in 2269 hours before its star, Beta Niobe, went supernova. The Enterprise crew discovered that the natives of the world had escaped their fate by time traveling to their world's past, using a time-travel device called an atavachron.[56]
name: Sarpeidon

description: Heavily fortified headquarters planet of the Cardassian "Twelfth Order" military division. (It is not in the same system as Sarpeidon as that system was destroyed in 2269).[57]
name: Sarpeidon V

description: Homeworld of the Sarthongians, and rich in archeological ruins that Vash considered exploring after parting ways with Picard.[39] Vash returns from the world with Q.[58]
name: Sarthong V

description: Sol VI. The Borg Cube passed Saturn on its way to Earth.[59]
name: Saturn

description: Homeworld of the Saurian species.[24] They are known for their popular Saurian brandy served in a characteristic curved bottle. Capt. Picard says that he once traded a bottle of old Saurian brandy for a rare Gorlan prayer stick.[60]
name: Sauria

description: A strange planet outside Federation territory that was visited by the USS Enterprise NCC-1701. The Scalosian inhabitants have a "hyper-accelerated" physical existence and move at a faster rate of time.[61]
name: Scalos

description: Planet where the infamous criminal known only as "The Albino", responsible for attacks against the Klingons, resides in a private fortress.[62]
name: Secarus IV

description: Planet near Draylon II.[63]
name: Sefalla Prime

description: One of two inhabited planets in the Beta Renner system. It is home of the cobra-headed Selay species who were at war with their sister planet Antica. Both worlds wished to join the Federation. The Enterprise-D transported delegates to difficult peace negotiations on Parliament.[64]
name: Selay

description: Delta Quadrant planet, site of a gambling tournament.[65]
name: Selek IV

description: Delta Quadrant planet mentioned to have a militaristic humanoid race that waged a brutal war with neighboring species.[66] Tom Paris and Neelix meet con artists posing as clerics from the planet.[67]
name: Selenia Prime

description: Destination of the USS Lalo which was destroyed en route by a Borg cube headed for Sector 001.[59]
name: Sentinel Minor IV

description: Destination of the colony ship SS Artemis which disappeared, eventually landing on Tau Cygna V.[68]
name: Septimis Minor

description: Planet that was headquarters of the Cardassian "Eleventh Order" military division. During the Dominion War, it was attacked and conquered by the Klingons.  The five-hundred thousand Cardassians of the Eleventh Order were all wiped out.[69]
name: Septimus III

description: Delta Quadrant homeworld of the advanced Serosian species who use pseudo-solid holographic generated servants called "isomorphs" and treat them as slave labor. One is driven insane and murders the crew of a Serosian ship.[70]
name: Seros

description: Federation colony near Cardassian space that was attacked around 2347 by the Cardassians in an event that became known as "The Setlik Massacre". Miles O'Brien was part of the Federation task force who battled the Cardassian invaders.[71][72][73][74]
name: Setlik III

description: The Vulcan name for a mythological planet that was the alleged source of all creation. It is also known as "Qui'Tu" by the Klingons, "Vorta Vor" by the Romulans, or "Eden" by people of Earth. Sha Ka Ree was believed by Spock's older half-brother Sybok to be located at the center of the galaxy, hidden behind the Great Barrier energy field. According to legend, the planet was where God resided. Instead, it was discovered that the world, which had a barren, unviable surface ecology, was actually a prison for a dangerous entity.[75]
name: Sha Ka Ree

description: Planet used in a Tamarian mythological tale about the characters Darmok and Jalad who faced off against a common enemy on an island called Tanagra.[12]
name: Shantil III

description: The Shelia star system is the home of the Sheliak, a classification R-3 non-humanoid species that claims Tau Cygna V, where a group of humans has established a colony. It is not clear which planet (or planets) the Sheliak occupy in the Shelia system.[68]
name: Shelia

description: An agricultural world near the Neutral Zone (in the era of ST:TOS) that is contested between the Klingons and the Federation.  Subject to near-catastrophic crop failures and famine conditions; on at least two occasions, the Federation transported massive quantities of grain to Sherman's Planet to stave off famine amongst the colonists.[76][77]
name: Sherman's Planet

description: Location of a Jem'Hadar breeding facility.[78]
name: Sheva II

description: A beautiful world inhabited by the "Parallax Colony", a group of free-spirits concerned only with love and pleasure. Lwaxana Troi introduced Worf's son Alexander to a holodeck simulation of a Parallax mudbath and to experience their "Laughing Hour".[79]
name: Shiralea VI

description: Site of a Federation outpost.[80]
name: Sierra VI

description: A star system with three inhabited worlds, those being the 3rd, 4th, and 6th planets respectively. Each is populated by different technologically primitive culture; however, Sigma Draconis VI was visited by the USS Enterprise where Captain Kirk chases down aliens who have stolen Spock's brain.[81]
name: Sigma Draconis

description: Star system, according to the trader Kivas Fajo, it is the only known source of hytritium.[82]
name: Sigma Erani

description: The Iotians established a 1920s gangster society, the result of cultural contamination of a missing book from the USS Horizon.[83]
name: Sigma Iota II

description: Delta Quadrant homeworld of the Sikarian species. The planet has a thick quartz mantle used as an amplification device in the Sikarian's advanced Spatial Trajector Transporter which the USS Voyager crew hoped could send them 40,000 light years closer to Federation space.[84]
name: Sikaris

description: Cardassian planet where the Cardassian Liberation Front was headquartered, and also one of eighteen worlds destroyed by Breen and Dominion forces in 2375.[85]
name: Simperia

description: Kivas Fajo was in possession of a one-of-a-kind vase by artist Mark Off-Zel of Sirrie IV.[82]
name: Sirrie IV

description: Planet in the Delphic Expanse settled by the humanoid Skagaran species. In the 19th Century, the aliens abducted a group of Human settlers from the north-western United States to use them as slave labor. Eventually the slaves had an uprising and overthrew their captors to become the dominant species of the planet.[86]
name: Skagaran colony

description: Kazon planet where rival Kazon sects congregate for talks.[87][88]
name: Sobras

description: Home planet of the Solari, where two factions have been at war for fifteen centuries. In 2265, the Enterprise-D takes the deaf-mute mediator named Rivas there to lead a delicate peace negotiation.[7] When Sisko is promoted to Captain and wants to tell Kasidy Yates about it, he learns that she is hauling a load of duranium to Solais V.[89]
name: Solais V

description: Site of a Bajoran terrorist raid.[90]
name: Solarion IV

description: Maquis colony in the Cardassian DMZ where Cmdr. Sisko forced the surrender of agents and their weapons.[53]
name: Solosos III

description: Homeworld of the Son'a species and capital world of the Son'a Solidarity.[91]
name: Son'a Prime

description: Planet mentioned by Prof. Galen whose inhabitants, the Satarran species, disdain mysteries.[2] The Satarrans waged a decades long war with a neighboring race, the Lysians.[92]
name: Sothis III

description: A Cardassian planet with thick jungles and the site of a Dominion base. In 2347, Worf and Jadzia Dax undergo a covert mission there to rescue a Cardassian defector who knew the fake identities of Founders hiding in the Alpha Quadrant.[93][94]
name: Soukara

description: Star system also known as Alpha Virginis. There is a Federation colony there which is known for its valuable Spican flame gems.[76]
name: Spica

description: A planet that in 2151 had active slave trade. The Ferengi pirates who hijacked the Enterprise NX-01 were planning to sell captured crew there.[95]
name: Stameris

description: Planetside Starbase facility. In 2268, the Enterprise-D drops off Kareen Brianon there for transport back to Earth. The name of the planet Starbase 6 was located on was not mentioned.[96] On stardate 4307.1, Starbase 6 lost contact with the USS Intrepid and sent rescue coordinates to the USS Enterprise NCC-1701[97]
name: Starbase 6

description: Planetside Starbase facility. The primary purpose of the station seems to be the handling of litigation matters. The name of the planet Starbase 11 was located on was never mentioned.[98][99]
name: Starbase 11

description: Planetside Starbase facility in the Haven (Gamma 400) system. The USS Dauntless and USS Sovereign use it as a base of operations in their investigation of the Vesuvi event.[100]
name: Starbase 12

description: Planetside Starbase facility. In 2365, the Enterprise-D stops at the base along route to the Endicor system. Riker bought some Owon eggs here.[101] In 2366, the Enterprise goes there again to investigate a distress call from the Ficus Sector.[102] The name of the planet Starbase 73 was located on was never mentioned.
name: Starbase 73

description: Two Romulan cruisers are detected by Starbase 123 on the way to the Beta Stromgren system to secure Tin Man.[103]
name: Starbase 123

description: Destination of the Enterprise after it leaves the Rana system at the end of TNG episode "The Survivors". Also the location of the static warp bubble trapping Dr. Beverly Crusher in the TNG episode "Remember Me".
name: Starbase 133

description: Enterprise's destination at end of the episode "Tin Man".[103]
name: Starbase 152

description: The Enterprise transports an emissary (K'Ehleyr, Worf's former mate) from Starbase 153 to the Boradis system.[54]
name: Starbase 153

description: Planetside Starbase facility located near Romulan space. It has orbital drydock stations. The name of the planet Starbase 234 was located on was never mentioned.[104] Capt. Picard goes there to investigate the disappearance of Ambassador Spock.[105]
name: Starbase 234

description: Planetside Starbase with extensive medical facilities. In 2365, Capt. Picard went there to undergo a cardiac replacement. The name of the planet Starbase 515 was located on was never mentioned.[106]
name: Starbase 515

description: Federation Starbase. Location of the Bonestell Recreation Facility where young Ensign Picard picked a fight with a group of Nausicaans, one of which stabbed him through the heart.[107] Recalling the incident, Picard refers to the station as "Farspace Starbase Earhart".[106]
name: Starbase Earhart

description: Planetside Federation Starbase. The Enterprise-D went there for an inspection of the warp core after a series of system failures.[108]
name: Starbase Montgomery

description: Destination of the Enterprise-D after it left the Darwin Genetic Research Station on Gagarin IV.[109]
name: Star Station India

description: Planet whose inhabitants, along with the people of Altec, makes up the Coalition of Madena. A political leader of Altec had issues with the rogue freighter captain Okona.[110]
name: Straleb

description: a Federation colony needing a rare vaccine from Ligon II.[111]
name: Styris IV

description: a planet in sector 3641, home of the Suliban people. The name of the planet is not mentioned.[33]
name: Suliban homeworld

description: Planet where Captain Picard was invited to by his associate Dr. Langford to assist in an archeological dig.[112]
name: Sulvin IV

description: Site of the Cliffs of Heaven in a holodeck program.[92]
name: Sumiko IV

description: Uninhabited planet where Commander Riker was poked by a poison thorn and later falls comatose from the infection.[113]
name: Surata IV

description: An indigenous name for Vulcan.[citation needed]
name: T'Khasi

description: Volcanic planet that shares an orbit with Vulcan.[1]
name: T'Khut

description: Homeworld of the T'Lani species.[2]
name: T'Lani Prime

description: World belonging to the T'Lani species which was wiped out in 2370 in a war against the Kellerun species.[2]
name: T'Lani III

description: Destination of the USS Enterprise-D before it became trapped in a cosmic string anomaly.[3]
name: T'lli Beta

description: Home of the Dominion allied T-Rogoran species in the Gamma Quadrant.[4]
name: T-Rogoran

description: The dying homeworld of the Tagran species, whose careless industrialization began destroying the atmosphere. On stardate 46192.3, the USS Enterprise-D undertakes a clean up mission of the atmosphere which proves fruitless. However, young intern crewmember Amanda Rogers (who was unknowingly a member of the Q) uses her godlike powers to save the planet.[5]
name: Tagra IV

description: Homeworld of the secretive Taguan species who have a rich historic culture studied by the Vulcans (the only species the Taguans allow to visit their world). The Federation Archaeology Council holds an annual symposium in orbit above the planet.[6]
name: Tagus III

description: Delta Quadrant homeworld of the Takarians species that laid at one end of the Barzan Wormhole.[7]
name: Takar II

description: Homeworld of the Takaran species (not to be confused with the Takarians), the planet has an inhospitable environment to most humanoid life.[8]
name: Takara

description: Home of the Talarian species.[9] The Enterprise encounters a disabled Talarian ship adrift in the Neutral Zone. (At one point in the episode, Capt. Picard describes the ship as "Taralian," but the subtitle track spells the name "Talarian.")[10]
name: Talarian homeworld

description: Homeworld of the Talaxian species.[11][12] The Talaxians were known as the Talax-ilzay in their "old tongue."[13]
name: Talax

description: Quark is accused of dealing with Markalian smugglers to acquire Tallonian crystals, illegal anywhere away from the Tallonian homeworld.[14]
name: Tallonian homeworld

description: Quarantined homeworld of the Talosian species, strange humanoids who can create realistic illusions.[15][16] Star Fleet General Order 7 quarantines the entire region against any and all contact under penalty of death because of the Talosians' abilities; any communication supposedly originating from the region is to be assumed false, without exceptions.
name: Talos IV

description: Homeworld of the metaphoric speaking Children of Tamar species.[17]
name: Tamar

description: Planet in the 39 Tauri system. Homeworld of the Tandarian species.[18]
name: Tandar Prime

description: A Federation prison colony where the warden, Dr. Tristan Adams, is discovered conducting cruel psychological experiments on the inmates. The planet is also referred to as Tantalus V.[19]
name: Tantalus

description: The cloudy homeworld of the Tanugan species, who have a harsh "guilty until proven innocent" justice system. Commander Riker was accused of murdering the Tanugan physicist Dr. Nel Apgar, who was experimenting on converting Krieger waves and had hoped to sell his Krieger-wave converter to Federation enemies as a weapon; the UFP's interest in the Krieger-wave converter had been primarily as a power source.[20]
name: Tanuga IV

description: Delta Quadrant planet once settled by Nakan colonists. The planet was to be evacuated, but the colonists were instead slaughtered by the rescue forces sent to help them leave. A memorial to the massacre remains on the surface which contains a synaptic generator and causes those who stand near it to receive flashes of images and the intense emotions of the event.[21]
name: Tarakis

description: System with a Federation colony.  In 2370, the USS Enterprise-D took on medical supplies destined for the system from the USS Lexington.[22]
name: Taranko colony

description: A swampy planet with a thick atmosphere visited by the USS Victory in 2362, to investigate the disappearance of 49 scientists from a Federation research station. Geordi La Forge was part of the investigating team. In 2367, La Forge and members of his search team were mysteriously drawn back to the planet and underwent a strange metamorphosis, turning into invisible amphibious beings that are native to the planet. The beings reproduce by infecting other races with a genetic parasite.[23]
name: Tarchannen III

description: The former homeworld of the Tarellian species who fought a civil war with biological weapons that wiped out nearly all of them. Some escaped into space looking for a cure.[24]
name: Tarellia

description: Class M homeworld of the Taresian species. The Planet is located in the Delta Quadrant and is populated by 90% females.[25]
name: Taresia

description: Homeworld of the Tarkaleans.[26][27][28][29]
name: Tarkalea

description: Home of the Tarlac species. It is one of three planets ruled over by the Son'a Solidarity.[30]
name: Tarlac homeworld

description: Site of a Federation post near the Neutral Zone, which Capt. Picard believed was destroyed by Romulans.[31]
name: Tarod IX

description: M-class moon of a Delta quadrant gas giant, used as a training site by the Ogla sect of the Kazon. Chakotay and a Kazon boy named Kar were marooned there.[32]
name: Tarok

description: Planet whose sole inhabitant is the alien named Tarquin.[33]
name: Tarquin's Planet

description: Location of Starbase 74, where the Enterprise-D drydocks for a computer upgrade.[34]
name: Tarsus III

description: Federation colony that was home to some members of James Kirk's family, who were killed in a mass genocide ordered by the colony's ruler Kodos.[35] Kevin Thomas Riley (Bruce Hyde), one of James Kirk's junior personnel, was born there and lost his family in the massacre.
name: Tarsus IV

description: Planet where Vash goes off to explore the ruins.[36]
name: Tartarus V

description: Star system of the home to an enigmatic race of beings which includes one known only as The Traveler. At maximum warp speeds it would take over 120 days to reach the planet from Starbase 133.[37]
name: Tau Alpha C

description: Planet in the Tau Ceti system. In 2368, Vice Admiral Janeway, (Capt. Janeway's father), drowned on the planet.[38]
name: Tau Ceti Prime

description: Planet where Picard first met his friend Captain Keel.[39] Non-canonical sources identify this planet as Kaferia and describe its inhabitants as insectoid bipeds who prefer maintenance of an alliance with the Federation to membership in it; in these non-canonical sources, they are also credited for eugenically tailoring some of the most delicious fruits known to Federation society.[citation needed]
name: Tau Ceti III

description: Home port planet of the simulation ship Kobayashi Maru. Planet's name was indicated on a readout screen.[40]
name: Tau Ceti IV

description: Colony where in 2274, the SS Artemis crashed on the surface and the survivors started a new civilization. In 2366, the Enterprise-D was assigned to remove the lost colony of humans against their will when the planet was annexed from the Federation by the Sheliak species. The planet is bathed in radiation harmful to humans but the colonists developed a natural resistance over time. To handle the relocation effort, Lt. Cmdr. Data was sent to planet since he was immune to the radiation effects.[41]
name: Tau Cygna V

description: Planet where Captain Janeway got her dog, Molly, as a puppy from a pound. Note: The planet most likely should have been Tau Ceti IV since Janeway's father was from Tau Ceti Prime.[42]
name: Taurus Ceti IV

description: A desolate planet near the Murasaki 312 quasar where the Galileo shuttle crashed. The planet is inhabited by primitive hostile giant humanoids.[43]
name: Taurus II

description: Location of Jem'Hadar facilities.[44]
name: Taurus III

description: Recreational planet.[45]
name: Tavela Minor

description: There is a frozen dessert on Tazna named Darmok..[17]
name: Tazna

description: World colonized by Denobulans.[46]
name: Teerza Prime

description: Data offers flowers from this world to Jenna D'Sora, with whom he is pursuing a romantic relationship.[47]
name: Telemarius IV

description: Homeworld of the Tellarite species.[48] Non-canonical resources equate the primary of this planet with 61 Cygni.
name: Tellar Prime

description: Delta Quadrant planet and home of the Telsian species.  In 2376, a mine on the planet was robbed by con artists disguised as USS Voyager personnel.[49]
name: Telsius

description: Planet near where Maquis members Chakotay and B'Elanna Torres destroyed two Federation Runabouts who answered their fake distress call.[50]
name: Teluridian IV

description: Federation colony.[51]
name: Tendara colony

description: Kira, Dax and Bashir answer a distress signal coming from one of the planets in the Teplan system in the Gamma Quadrant.[52]
name: Teplan system

description: Uninhabited planet where Dr. Noonien Soong and his wife Juliana O'Donnell fled after the destruction of Omicron Theta colony to continue their work on androids.[53]
name: Terlina III

description: Planet visited by Dr. Gideon Seyetik and his wife Nidell. An accident there caused Nidell to lose control of her psychic powers and an alter ego, Fenna, was created. Fenna caused problems aboard DS9.[54]
name: Terosa Prime

description: also known as Eta Cassiopeia III, was one of the first Earth-colonized planets. Terra Nova was Earth's "great experiment," and was an early human colonization mission, which set its sights on the closest habitable planet from Earth. The world was 20 light-years from Earth, and the early warp drive colony ship heading there took 9 years to reach it.[55] All adults from the original colony were killed after a radioactive asteroid struck the planet. The children survived by going underground and living in caves.
name: Terra Nova

description: Chakotay spars with a Terrellian on the holodeck.[56]
name: Terrellian homeworld

description: Planet threatened by an asteroid that the Enterprise-D tries to push off course with a new tractor beam system.[57]
name: Tessen III

description: Planet visited by the Enterprise NX-01 in 2152, where a crewman contracted Rigellian Fever and started an epidemic forcing Dr. Phlox to inoculate the entire crew.[58]
name: Tessik Prime

description: A gas giant planet in the Tethys system. Data faked information regarding the system to hide the existence of the xenophobic isolationist Paxan species, a race who did not want to be known by outsiders. The Paxans erased the crew's memories save for Data, because he was inorganic, but made him vow to never reveal their existence.[59]
name: Tethys III

description: Planet known for its black market activity.[60]
name: Thalos IV

description: Homeworld of the Thalian species. Known for their unique chocolate mousse, a delicacy made from centuries-old cacao beans.[61]
name: Thalos VII

description: Planet where in 2073, a defective warp core conduit installed aboard the Enterprise-D was manufactured. Unfortunately, the conduit was infested with interphasic organisms which caused the warp core to fail.[62]
name: Thanatos VII

description: Homeworld of the discorporate Thasian species and inhospitable to most other races. The crew of the USS Antares finds a teenage boy named Charles Evans (Robert Walker Jr.) stranded on the planet. The Thasians had granted him psycho-energetic powers for survival, which, because of his lack of maturity and the fact that he was going through adolescence—and its corresponding identity crisis—when they were discovered, proved to be as dangerous as if he had been a child with a fully loaded handgun.[63] Because the Thasians were discorporate, Evans lamented, just before being taken back to Thasus, "I-I can't even TOUCH them!!!"
name: Thasus

description: Planet from which comes a special dessert Picard wanted to serve to Nella Daren, a Commander he was "dating" for a time aboard the Enterprise.[64]
name: Thelka IV

description: Homeworld of the Xyrillian species. The Xyrillian female Ah'len took Trip to an image of Thera on her ship's holodeck.[65]
name: Thera

description: Gas giant planet investigated by the Enterprise-D after having traced the ancient NASA spacecraft Charybdis here. An unknown alien intelligence recreated a 20th-century hotel/casino from a novel called The Hotel Royale on a plane of frozen methane for the craft's only surviving crewmember.[66]
name: Theta 116 VIII

description: The Enterprise is scheduled to meet the USS Yorktown to carry perishable drugs to the Federation colony on Theta VII.[67]
name: Theta VII

description: a Federation colony.[68]
name: Theta Cygni XII

description: The homeworld of the xenophobic Melkotian species visited by the USS Enterprise NCC-1701.[69]
name: Theta Kiokis II

description: Class Y Homeworld of the Tholian species.[71] Benjamin Sisko gives Kasidy Yates a gift of Tholian silk which he got from the Tholian ambassador.[72] Data relates that Will Riker calculated a sensory blind spot on a Tholian vessel and hid within it during a battle simulation.[73]
name: Tholia

description: Planet where it only rains twice a year, producing Thurasian Rain Water, a delightful drink which Guinan served Counselor Deanna Troi.[74]
name: Thurasia

description: Klingon asteroid belt containing a military base.[75]
name: Ti'Acor

description: Planet mentioned as the homeworld of Dr. Sevrin. It is the homeworld of the Tiburonians whose name for the planet is Simeran. It is in the Omega Fornacis A star system.[76]
name: Tiburon

description: A planet fallen into anarchy that Riker is ordered to infiltrate.[77]
name: Tilonus IV

description: An unnamed planet that had been deserted by an advanced species who created a doughnut-shaped device, a sapient time portal calling itself "The Guardian of Forever," that would transport a being to any place and time they desired. It was first discovered by Captain James Kirk of the USS Enterprise at an unknown stardate in which Dr. Leonard McCoy accidentally stumbled in, sending him to 1930s Earth. They retrieved McCoy, and left the planet with no definite coordinates so that no ship could repeat any accidents.[78] TAS, however, said that in the animated installment "Yesteryear," strictly regulated historical research was conducted there; but when Spock accidentally erased his own existence, he had to use the Guardian of Forever to undo that erasure, and finally contact with the Time Planet was banned altogether.
name: Time Planet

description: Planet where the fifth-largest Ferengi controlled pergium mine resides.[79]
name: Timor II

description: Colonized moon of Saturn.[80]
name: Titan

description: Planet where Miles O'Brien almost stepped on a Lycosa Tarantula. He takes the spider as his pet Christina.[81]
name: Titus IV
