description: A neutral planet near Cardassian space. Captain Picard went there in 2366 to negotiate a Federation-Cardassian peace treaty, but instead, he was abducted and interrogated by Gul Madred.[82]
name: Tohvun III

description: Destination of Miles O'Brien and his wife pregnant Keiko for a botanical study, during which their runabout is damaged, and Keiko injured. The fetus of Keiko's unborn son is transferred to Major Kira by Dr. Bashir and Kira carries the child to full term.[83]
name: Torad V

description: While reliving a massacre on Tarakis under the influence of a synaptic generator, Chakotay is promised a week's R&R on Toranius Prime after he completes the mission.[21]
name: Toranius Prime

description: Uninhabited Gamma Quadrant planet rich in valuable "cormaline" deposits. Captain Sisko leads a team there to determine the feasibility of establishing a mining colony so far from Federation space.[84]
name: Torga IV

description: Planet near Cardassian space where Captain Picard hires a Ferengi smuggler to take him and Dr. Crusher to Celtris III.[85]
name: Torman V

description: Planet where the Klingon Kor became drunk in a tavern and revealed he knew the whereabouts of the ancient "Sword of Kahless."[86]
name: Torna IV

description: Homeworld of the insectoid Jarada species.[87]
name: Torona IV

description: A desert Beta Quadrant planet. Homeworld of the Torothan species visited by the Enterprise NX-01 in 2152. Captain Archer meets Zobral, a terrorist leader, who tries to force Archer to help him fight his political enemies.[88]
name: Toroth

description: Planet in Cardassian space where a Cardassian-Dominion shipyard was located.[44]
name: Torros III

description: Maquis colony. In 2373 Captain Sisko threatened to render the planet uninhabitable unless Maquis agents hiding there surrendered themselves and their weapons.[89]
name: Tracken II

description: Site of a famous Klingon battle.[90]
name: Tranome Sar

description: World destroyed by Cardassians.[91]
name: Trebus

description: Location of Cardassian starbase.[92]
name: Trelka V

description: Ringed planet.[93]
name: Trelkis III

description: A planet with a small Federation archeology team stationed there to investigate ancient ruins of an extinct civilization.[94] Non-canonical sources call it Epsilon Indi III.[citation needed]
name: Triacus

description: Planet where Dr. Arik Soong fled after stealing augmented human embryos to raise on his own.[95][96]
name: Trialas IV

description: Homeworld of the Triannon species located in the Delphic Expanse.[97]
name: Triannon

description: (a.k.a. Trillius Prime) Homeworld of the symbiotic Trill species.[98] Ensign Mayweather's family resided there for a time.[99]
name: Trill

description: Location of a Federation colony and outpost.[100]
name: Triona

description: Planet in the M-24 Alpha system, with three suns, controlled by at least three once-humanoid beings, now existing as disembodied entities in subsurface vaults, who once captured slaves ("Thralls") from other worlds and made them fight in gladiatorial games for their entertainment.[101]
name: Triskelion

description: Planet visited by the USS Enterprise NCC-1701 whose people sought peace with a warring neighbor world, Elas, through an arranged marriage.[102]
name: Troyius

description: Site of a failed Federation colony that fell into anarchy and eventually severed ties to the Federation. Birthplace of Natasha and Ishara Yar.[103]
name: Turkana IV

description: An uninhabited planet where Captain Kirk chases an incorporeal vampiric entity down to kill it.[67]
name: Tycho IV

description: Desolate, uninhabited planet where the Prophet's "Orb of the Emissary" artifact was hidden.[104]
name: Tyree

description: Homeworld of the Tyrellian species and one of the few planets known for lacking magnetic poles. It has no atmosphere.[105]
name: Tyrellia

description: Site of the experimental "particle fountain" mining technology.[106]
name: Tyrus VII-A

description: Homeworld of the Tzenkethi species, whose Autarch is overturned in a coup d'état.[107][108]
name: Tzenketh

description: Planet near which the Duras Sisters tried to sell illegally mined magnasite to a Yridian smuggler.[110]
name: Ufandi III

description: Homeworld of the telepathic Ullian species.[111]
name: Ullian homeworld

description: Planet used by Valerians smuggling weapon materials to the Cardassians.[112]
name: Ultima Thule

description: Former Federation colony in the Cardassian DMZ. It was believed Cardassian saboteurs fouled food replicators in an attempt to poison colonists who refused to leave.[113]
name: Umoth VIII

description: Cardassian planet where a secret Obsidian Order safehouse was located.[114]
name: Unefra III

description: Delta Quadrant planet inhabited by a pre-warp civilization. At the turn of the 23rd Century, the first Earth, warp-capable, unmanned probe Friendship 1 landed on Uxal whose inhabitants reverse engineered its technology and developed their own warp drive as well as antimatter weapons. Rival factions on the planet went to war over technology rights until an antimatter bomb was detonated which destroyed the planet's ecosystem. In 2377, the USS Voyager came upon Uxal and helped the remaining survivors to clean up the atmosphere, thus restoring Uxal's environment.[115]
name: Uxal

description: Planet in the Delta Quadrant, home of the Vaadwaur species.[116] The Vaadwaur were a warrior race, nearly exterminated in a war with the Turei and their allies 900 years earlier.[13]
name: Vaadwaur homeworld

description: An M-class planet in the Cabral sector chosen to transplant a community of Boraalans whose original home, Boraal II, became uninhabitable.[117]
name: Vacca VI

description: Gamma Quadrant planet where an isolated race resides who believe they are the only intelligent species in the universe.[36]
name: Vadris III

description: An otherwise uninhabited planet in the Zed Lapis sector, home of Armus, who holds Deanna Troi and a shuttle pilot captive and kills Tasha Yar.[118]
name: Vagra II

description: Site of Bajoran rebel camp.[119]
name: Valo II

description: Krios and Valt Minor are two warring planets.[120]
name: Valt Minor

description: Cardassian controlled planet.[121]
name: Vanden Prime

description: A planetoid in elliptical orbit around binary stars where Dr. Paul Manheim built a secret laboratory to conduct his dimensional time experiments in private.[122]
name: Vandor IV

description: Dominion allied planet in the Gamma Quadrant.[123]
name: Vandros IV

description: Homeworld of the Varalan species.[124]
name: Varala

description: A Federation colony whose inhabitants, as James Kirk discovered, were murdered by his mirror-universe counterpart.[125] It is unclear whether Vega IX also exists in our James Kirk's universe. In TNG episode "Tin Man" a Vega IX probe is mentioned which passed through the Beta Stromgren system, but it is not clear if this refers to the planet Vega IX or if this is merely the name of the probe.
name: Vega IX

description: Homeworld of the long-lived Vega Reticuli species.[126]
name: Vega Reticuli

description: A lifeless planet where the Federation had set up a terraforming station. It was revealed that Velara III already had silicon-based life and the terraforming operation was unknowingly destroying them. Apparently close to the Pleiades cluster, since that was what Enterprise D was mapping, before arriving.[127]
name: Velara III

description: Cardassian controlled planet where a Bajoran internment camp was located.[128]
name: Velos VII

description: Cardassian planet attacked by the Maquis in 2373, who used a nerve agent to drive the Cardassians from the planet. The Maquis later took the planet over.[89]
name: Veloz Prime

description: Planet whose people were engaged in a simulated war with the people of Eminiar VII.[129]
name: Vendikar

description: Planet believed to be the birthplace of Tret Akleen, "father" of the Cardassian Union.[130]
name: Ventani II

description: Home of the Ventaxians, who signed a contract with the mythical demon Ardra. Capt. Picard proved that Ardra was a hoax, impersonated by a woman in a cloaked ship in orbit above the planet.[131]
name: Ventax II

description: Sol II. A hostile rocky planet. Venus was terraformed or in the process of being terraformed in the 24th century.[citation needed]
name: Venus

description: Planet used by the Orions as a processing station for their slave trade.[95]
name: Verex III

description: An unsettled Class M planet. It is the world where Captain Kirk is killed after helping Captain Picard stop the renegade scientist Dr. Tolian Soran from his rendezvous with the Nexus energy ribbon. After a stealth attack by the Klingon Duras sisters, the Enterprise-D suffered a warp core breach and was destroyed in orbit of Veridian III. However, the saucer section managed to separate, and survived a crash landing on the planet's surface. The crew were later rescued.[132]
name: Veridian III

description: Sister planet to Veridian III which supports a pre-industrial humanoid society, the lives of which were threatened by Dr. Tolian Soran's star destroying weapon.[132]
name: Veridian IV

description: Planet known for having a "wildest sky in the Alpha Quadrant".[133]
name: Vico V

description: Site of the final genetic clue in Dr. Galen's search for the origin of humanoid species.[134]
name: Vilmoran II

description: Homeworld of the Vissian species.[135]
name: Vissia

description: Former Federation colony given up to the Cardassians, several colonists rebelled and attacked the Cardassian freighter Bok'Nor.[136]
name: Volan II

description: Sister planet to Volan II and a former Federation colony handed over to the Cardassians. Like the settlers of Volan II, some resisted the Cardassian take over and formed the Maquis rebellion.[136]
name: Volan III

description: Planet in Ferengi space.[137]
name: Volchok Prime

description: A dry, hostile planet in the 40 Eridani A system that is the homeworld of the Vulcan people,[1][138][139][140] who are also known as Vulcanians.[129]
name: Vulcan

description: Gamma Quadrant homeworld of the Wadi people, the first Gamma Quadrant species with which the crew of DS9 makes first contact.[141]
name: Wadi

description: Uninhabited system close to Earth consisting of a red dwarf star, and location of the Battle of Wolf 359 between the Borg and the United Federation of Planets.[142] Dr. Riley Frazier, former science officer of the Roosevelt, was assimilated at Wolf 359,[143]  and Jennifer Sisko was killed in the battle.
name: Wolf 359

description: See Babel.
name: Wolf 424

description: Planet dedicated to "adult entertainment."[144]
name: Wrigley's Pleasure Planet

description: Homeworld of the Wysanti species, in the Delta Quadrant.[145]
name: Wysanti

description: Watery home planet of the Xanthan species, known for its numerous floating bazaars.[146]
name: Xanthan homeworld

description: Destination of the USS Enterprise-D.[147]
name: Xanthras III

description: Homeworld of the Xantorian species.[148]
name: Xantoras

description: Star system where Jean-Luc Picard receives the USS Stargazer from the Ferengi[149] and where Picard later searches for Daimon Bok.[150]
name: Xendi Sabu

description: A starship repair facility near the Xendi Sabu system, possibly under control of private corporations. In 2364, the Enterprise-D towed the derelict USS Stargazer to the station.[149]
name: Xendi Starbase 9

description: Rumored to have a mythological city called Neinman, akin to the legends of Earth's Atlantis.[151]
name: Xerxes VII

description: Top secret planetary home of the Xindi Council.[152]
name: Xindi Council Planet

description: Xindi homeworld. Was destroyed during the Xindi Civil War.[153]
name: Xindus

description: Dominion-allied planet and homeworld of the Yaderian species, in the Gamma Quadrant.[154]
name: Yadera Prime

description: Planet that some Yaderians fled to when the Dominion invaded their planet, Yadera Prime.[154]
name: Yadera II

description: Home of the Yalidian species and supposedly rich in dilithium deposits.[155]
name: Yalidian homeworld

description: Home of the Yalosian species, who breathe a highly corrosive hydrogen fluoride atmosphere. A Yalosian ambassador visited DS9.[114]
name: Yalos

description: Asteroid with a habitable hollow core and an entire civilization living inside.[156]
name: Yonada

description: Beta Quadrant homeworld of the Yridian species, who are known for their smuggling[136] and illicit trade businesses, as well as the selling and trading of sensitive information.[157] Garak suspects that a Yridian whom he owes money may be responsible for the attempt on his life.[114] After playing darts with Morn, Bashir tells him he couldn't hit the side of an Yridian Yak.[158] The Yridians, whom Seven of Nine describes as species 6291, were considered extinct until rediscovered by Captain Rudy Ransom.[159]
name: Yridia

description: Federation colony, young Harry Bernard grew up on the planet where his father raised dolphins.[151]
name: Zadar IV

description: The Zahl homeworld is in spatial grid 005 of the Delta Quadrant. The Zahl are enemies of the Krenim.[160]
name: Zahl homeworld

description: Homeworld of the Zakdorn species.[73]
name: Zakdorn

description: Homeworld of the militaristic Zalkonian species. Members of the Zalkonian race were undergoing an evolutionary metamorphosis, shedding their physical bodies and becoming entities of pure energy. Fearful of this fact, the Zalkonian government was evilly hunting down and killing those showing any signs of change—unfortunately for their villainy, one such Zalkonian did indeed survive and succeed in so metamorphosing completely.[161]
name: Zalkon

description: Homeworld of the Zaldan.
name: Zalda

description: Homeworld of the Zaranite species, members of the UFP and who were seen briefly in the movies, Star Trek: The Motion Picture, and Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home. The beings appear to wear gas masks.[1]
name: Zaran II

description: Location of a starbase where Chief Miles O'Brien once served and from when O'Brien recalls his encounter with Talarian Hook Spiders which infested a Jeffries Tube he had to work in.[81]
name: Zayra IV

description: Star system being surveyed by the USS Enterprise D when it gets an emergency call from Deanna Troi's shuttle, which has crashed on Vagra II.[118]
name: Zed Lapis

description: "Outer" planet of its system, whose apparently peaceful inhabitants, the Zeons, were attacked by the "inner" planet, Ekos.[162]
name: Zeon

description: A remote Federation colony.[163]
name: Zeta Alpha II

description: Also known as Neural, is a planet featured in the TOS episode "A Private Little War" where The Klingons are caught influencing the technological development of the planet's primitive inhabitants.
name: Zeta Boötis III

description: Former homeworld of the Zetarians, beings of energy whose planet was destroyed in a cataclysm. Those Zetarians who survived became patterns of noncorporeal energy who wandered through space in search of a living body they could inhabit.[164]
name: Zetar

description: The home planet of the Zibalian race, of whom trader/smuggler Kivas Fajo, who kidnaps Data is a member. Defending his greed and immorality, he blames the traits on a desperate youth "wasted on the streets of Zibalia".[165]
name: Zibalia

description: A planet where Jean-Luc Picard once sought shore leave.[166]
name: Zytchin III
